abstract_summ: Following from this context, this article presents the random oversampling and weighted class loss function approach for unbiased fine-tuned learning (transfer learning) in various state-of-the-art deep learning approaches such as baseline ResNet, Inception-v3, Inception ResNet-v2, DenseNet169, and NASNetLarge to perform binary classification (as normal and COVID-19 cases) and also multi-class classification (as COVID-19, pneumonia, and normal case) of posteroanterior CXR images.Using the data from 920 COVID-19 and 1,073 non-COVID-19 pneumonia patients, we developed a modified DenseNet-264 model, COVIDNet, to classify CT images to either class.Recently, with the release of publicly available datasets of corona positive patients comprising of computed tomography (CT) and chest X-ray (CXR) imaging; scientists, researchers and healthcare experts are contributing for faster and automated diagnosis of COVID-19 by identifying pulmonary infections using deep learning approaches to achieve better cure and treatment.We used 15,959 CXR images of 15,854 patients, covering normal, pneumonia, and COVID-19 cases.These datasets have limited samples concerned with the positive COVID-19 cases, which raise the challenge for unbiased learning.
title_summ: Assisting Scalable Diagnosis Automatically via CT Images in the Combat against COVID-19DeepCOVIDExplainer: Explainable COVID-19 Diagnosis Based on Chest X-ray ImagesAutomated diagnosis of COVID-19 with limited posteroanterior chest X-ray images using fine-tuned deep neural networks
title_abstract_phrases: Following from this context, this article presents the random oversampling and weighted class loss function approach for unbiased fine-tuned learning (transfer learning) in various state-of-the-art deep learning approaches such as baseline ResNet, Inception-v3, Inception ResNet-v2, DenseNet169, and NASNetLarge to perform binary classification (as normal and COVID-19 cases) and also multi-class classification (as COVID-19, pneumonia, and normal case) of posteroanterior CXR images.Recently, with the release of publicly available datasets of corona positive patients comprising of computed tomography (CT) and chest X-ray (CXR) imaging; scientists, researchers and healthcare experts are contributing for faster and automated diagnosis of COVID-19 by identifying pulmonary infections using deep learning approaches to achieve better cure and treatment.Using the data from 920 COVID-19 and 1,073 non-COVID-19 pneumonia patients, we developed a modified DenseNet-264 model, COVIDNet, to classify CT images to either class.We used 15,959 CXR images of 15,854 patients, covering normal, pneumonia, and COVID-19 cases.Automated diagnosis of COVID-19 with limited posteroanterior chest X-ray images using fine-tuned deep neural networksThe novel coronavirus 2019 (COVID-19) is a respiratory syndrome that resembles pneumonia.
